bibl.title: The Mummy of the 'Embroideress' and the Contents of her Grave.
bibl.note: Brussels, Royal Museums of Art and History, inv. E. 1045. - 1. Introduction. - 2. Acquisition at the Guimet Auction in 1901 and facts on the excavation and exhibition supplied by Albert Gayet. - 3. Identification of the textiles. - 4. Identification of the grave contents. - 5. Conclusions. [The so-called embroideress Euphemia lived most probably in the very late 5th, the 6th century or even the early 7th century AD.]

bibl.title: assisted by Elisabeth Ehler, Dress Accessories of the 1st Millennium AD from Egypt. Proceedings of the 6th Conference of the Research Group 'Textiles from the Nile Valley', Antwerp, 2-3 October 2009.

bibl.seg: Van Raemdonck Mieke, Chris Verhecken-Lammens and Daniël De Jonghe, The Mummy of the 'Embroideress' and the Contents of her Grave.

Antoine De Moor and Cäcilia Fluck (Edd.), assisted by Elisabeth Ehler, Dress Accessories of the 1st Millennium AD from Egypt. Proceedings of the 6th Conference of the Research Group 'Textiles from the Nile Valley', Antwerp, 2-3 October 2009 (Tielt, 2011) pp. 222-235, 15 figg. n./bl. et coul.

Brussels, Royal Museums of Art and History, inv. E. 1045. - 1. Introduction. - 2. Acquisition at the Guimet Auction in 1901 and facts on the excavation and exhibition supplied by Albert Gayet. - 3. Identification of the textiles. - 4. Identification of the grave contents. - 5. Conclusions. [The so-called embroideress Euphemia lived most probably in the very late 5th, the 6th century or even the early 7th century AD.]
